div.p: This paper develops the disturbance observer based integral sliding mode control (DOB-ISMC) approach for continuous-time linear systems with mismatched disturbances or uncertainties. The disturbance observer is proposed to generate the disturbance estimate, which can be incorporated in the controller to counteract the disturbance. With the help of the proposed disturbance observer, both the memoryless and memory-based integral sliding surfaces and integral sliding mode controllers are developed, respectively, and two approaches, H∞ control and stead-state output based approaches, are proposed to design the controller and disturbance rejection gains. Finally, the effectiveness and applicability of the proposed technique are illustrated by numerical example and real-time experiment.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: D URING the past few decades, sliding mode control (SMC) as a powerful nonlinear control technique has been extensively investigated because of its insensitivity and complete robustness to the so-called matched uncertainties or disturbances [1]- [5]. It is worth mentioning that, the system possess the property of insensitivity and complete robustness to the matched uncertainties or disturbances during the sliding mode, while might be sensitive to the matched uncertainties or disturbances during the reaching mode. To guarantee the system possess the insensitivity or complete robustness throughout an entire response of the system starting from the initial time instance, the so-called integral SMC (ISMC). In addition to the absence of a reaching phase feature, the ISMC design also maintains the aforementioned advantages of conventional SMC. In recent few years, the ISMC has been received a lot of attention, see, e.g., [6]- [9] and the references therein.

It should be pointed out that, the invariance property against the matched uncertainties or disturbances is accomplished by incorporating a discontinuous term in the controller, which results in the high frequency chattering behavior of the input and the sliding surface function. To reduce or even eliminate the chattering effects, the simple and attractive approach is to soften the discontinuous control term by its continuous approximation at the cost of a slight deterioration of control performances. For example, the signum function sgn(σ(t)) in the controller can be approximated by the saturation function sat(σ(t)) or σ(t) σ(t) +δ with σ(t) being the sliding surface function and δ being a sufficient small scalar. More recently, several authors introduce a disturbance observer in SMC to alleviate the chattering effects, the basic idea is to construct the SMC law by incorporating the disturbance estimate to compensate the disturbance straightforwardly. In [10], the disturbance observer based SMC approach is developed for second-order system with mismatched uncertainties, and the results are extended in [11]. In [12], the adaptive neural output feedback control scheme is proposed for uncertain nonlinear systems with unknown hysteresis, external disturbances and unmeasured states. For the discrete-time systems, if the disturbances vary slowly between within each sampling interval, then the disturbance d(k) can be approximated by d(k -1), and d(k -1) can be implemented in the controller to cancel the unknown present disturbance d(k) [7], [13].

In this paper, the disturbance observer based integral sliding mode control (DOB-ISMC) problems will be addressed for continuous-time linear systems with mismatched disturbance. In [10], the DOB-based SMC is considered for a special second order system with mismatched uncertainties. The authors in [11] improve the SMC approaches for secondorder systems proposed in [10] to general n-th order systems with mismatched uncertainties, and some novel disturbance observers and sliding surfaces are presented. Motivated by [10]- [12], [15], in this paper, the plant is a general linear system with mismatched disturbance, and both the memoryless and memory-based DOB-integral sliding surfaces are proposed based on the disturbance estimates. Then, the H ∞ control and stead-state output based approaches have been presented to design the controller and the disturbance rejection gains. Furthermore, both the robust and adaptive sliding mode controllers are also designed. The main contributions of this paper are: 1) The disturbance observer is proposed for general linear system with mismatched disturbance, and the disturbance estimate based integral sliding surface and integral sliding mode controller are also established; 2) The H ∞ control and stead-state output based strategies are given to design the controller gain and disturbance rejection gain;

3) The memory-based integral sliding surface and integral sliding mode control approach are also proposed to improve the transient control performance. Finally, simulations and experiments are carried out to validate the proposed method.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, the DOB-ISMC problem for continuoustime linear systems mismatched disturbance or uncertainties is investigated. To counteract the disturbance, the disturbance estimate, generated by disturbance observer, is incorporated in the sliding surfaces and controllers. The memoryless and memory-based DOB-ISMC approaches are developed respectively to design the integral sliding surfaces and integral sliding mode controllers. It can be seen that the proposed memorybased DOB-ISMC can results in the better transient control performances. Numerical example and experiment are given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed control approaches.
Motivated by the recent important works [21]- [24], our future attention will be devoted on designing the sliding mode controllers for networked control systems (NCSs) and process control systems.
